author: minhminh

description.text:
What we know about Egypt's ancient civilization comes from what was left behind. Archaeologists scour the region for remnants to piece together pictures of the past, but some clues are hard to miss: at six and a half million ton, taller than the Statue of Liberty, and as wide as 10 football fields, the Great Pyramid of Giza can be seen from space.  
Now with MakerBot's second curriculum unit, teachers and students,  can download and 3D print their very own model for use in the classroom!

Infill: 3%
Shells: 2
Resolution: Standard

The Great Pyramid Giza
What can this model tell us about Ancient Egyptian culture? Grades
3-5 Class periods
2-3

Learning Objectives
Students will understand the following:
  • Explain the meaning of the word artifact.
  • Explain an example of size and scale of the pyramids.
  • Discuss the purpose of pyramids.

Overview
What purpose do the Egyptian pyramids serve? How do the pyramids tell us about the culture of ancient Egypt? Historically, they housed and protected the Pharaoh and his belongings after death; presently, they lead archaeologists to understandings of ancient Egyptian culture.

Materials
  • One computer with connection to the Internet; one MakerBot Replicator 2 Desktop 3D Printer.
  • Great Pyramid of Giza 3D models (pyramid_Slidepiece.obj, pyramid_Mainpiece.obj)
  • Paper, pencils, poster boards, markers

Lesson Plan Instructions
This lesson consists of three learning activities that build upon one another. Activity 1 introduces students to artifacts and archaeology. Activity 2 considers pyramids as artifacts and examines the scale of these structures. Activity 3 asks students what clues pyramids give us about ancient Egyptians.

DAY 1: Messages in Stone
Explain to your students where the pyramids located, how big they are, and ask them what these structures tell us about ancient Egyptians by observing and analyzing tomb artifacts. Search the following images:
  • Mummy case
  • Mummy mask
  • Mummy
  • Peasants Driving Cattle and Fishing
  • Ka aper with Funerary Offerings
  • Papyrus of Nes-min, Weighing heart of the dead man
  • Mummy mask
  • Chantress Mummy coffin
    • Remind your students that ancient Egyptians built pyramids as tombs for their pharaohs. But what kind of person would want such a great structure built? Proud? Self-important? Powerful? See examples of pharaohs and court dynastic figures available through Exploring Ancient World Cultures, or searching online for images of the following:
  • Amenhotep III
  • Amenemhat III
  • Statute of Minemheb
    • The pyramids contained chambers filled with expensive objects that were buried with furniture, jewelry, games, and food. Why did the pharaohs need these things? (Afterlife) The ancient Egyptians had no cranes or machines to help them move and cut the stone blocks used in the pyramids. They had to do it all by hand. Many of the blocks weighed the same as 25 refrigerators. What does this tell us about the ancient Egyptians? Ask your students, how do they suppose they were able to move these huge blocks? The pyramids pointed toward the sky, which delivers another message about the ancient Egyptians. (the Egyptians believed that their pharaoh was a god and that he would rise up and join the other gods after his death. He would symbolically climb the pyramid's sloping sides to the sky, where he would live forever.) Whether or not the pharaohs lived forever, their stone structures endure. More than 4,000 years after they were built, the pyramids of the ancient Egyptians continue to be monuments with a message.

DAY 2: Scale of the Structures
Build around 2560 B.C., the Great Pyramid of Giza is the last survivor of the Seven Wonders of the World, and until the early 20th century was the tallest building in the world. The Great Pyramid dominates the plateau of Giza. Students can get a sense of the scale and magnificence of the pyramids from virtual reality views available through Pyramids: The Inside Story and on Nova: Pyramids. Building the Great Pyramid was a huge task. Your students can learn about it by watching the flash animation at the British Museum's Ancient Egypt site. Here are some quick facts:
  • Height: taller than the Statue of Liberty.
  • Weight: more than 2 million blocks of stone, each about 2.5 tons (the weight of about 25 refrigerators)
  • steep of the sides
  • Width at the base: approximately 10 football fields.

DAY 3: What is an Artifact?
Tell your students that they will dig into the past to find clues about lost civilizations. People who do this kind of job have a special name. Do any of your students know what they are called? (Archaeologists, from the Greek word, arkhaio meaning ancient.) Archaeologists search the earth for evidence of past civilizations. Like digging detectives, they try to find clues about how people used to live. Clues can come in all shapes and sizes. Show the students these artifacts from the following websites:
  • Carved wall relief
  • Palette
  • Sculpture
  • Haremhab statue
  • Coffin
  • Jewelry
  • Tomb
    • Mention that all of these things are called artifacts. An artifact is something created by humans usually for a practical purpose. Use this definition with your students to brainstorm on examples of familiar artifacts. Where did they see these artifacts? When did they originally exist? Arrange for your students to locate Egypt on a map. Now that students have located the pyramids, let them be virtual archaeologists and find out what the pyramids tell us about the ancient Egyptians.

Assessment
Turn back to the learning objectives for this lesson: What do the pyramids and the artifacts found in them tell us about ancient Egyptians' attitudes toward death? What do they tell us about life in ancient Egypt? Assign the following activities to teams to research and present findings to their classmates.
  • Team Geographers: Research the geographic location of the Great Pyramid of Giza and determine the environmental conditions of the time in which it was constructed.
  • Team Architects: Determine measurement, material, and construction methods used to build the Great Pyramid of Giza.
  • Team Archaeologists: Identify artifacts found within and around the Great Pyramid of Giza, then determine their function(s).
  • Team Historians: Create a timeline for the period when pyramids were created. Record rulers, their dynasty, and identify other positions held by Egyptians during the time.
    • Then, students can collectively construct an Ancient Egypt timeline.
Source: http://edsitement.neh.gov/

Coffee Saver is a project to create a reusable and versatile cap for an open bag of coffee granules, which can be produced on a 3D Printer. The main CAD software used for this project is OpenSCAD with additional functionality provided by Dan Kirshner's OpenSCAD Threading Library and PGreenland's Text Library. Version 3 allows the cap to be placed over the open bag and clamped in place by the two external clips. This Thing has been tested on a Makerbot Replicator 2X. For more information please see the Github Repository here...

This is a mount I made to hold a "CANZ" bluetooth speaker to the underside of my windscreen.  
The speaker can be found at Walmart, I got extreme hold 3M double sided tape at Thisens, along with a short nylon strap, the only other thing needed is a pad to wrap around the speaker to make a snug fit. I used a non-slip dash pad that usually holds a cell phone on your car, but you could use something else like a mouse pad I'm sure.  
It works great and sounds awesome, it does get a little harder to hear over about 45 mph but that's just wind noise.

I was looking for an adapter to put my 2.5" SSD drive in a 3.5" HDD bay, and found several nice designs, but none that could be screwed in from underneath, so I made one with all modern holes. It is possible to mount both the drive and the adapter in several different alignments and orientations. Does not obstruct airflow. The version with sunk screw holes can be mounted flat against a surface, with no screw heads from the small drive protruding from the bottom. The minimalist versions have lower sides, to save plastic and print time: However, it is less compliant with the 3.5" standard. Usually no biggie though. Measurements taken from datasheet.octopart.com/FFD-25-IDEP-2048-N-A-M-Systems-datasheet-4668.pdf This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit online at https://tinkercad.com/things/0NNJxmj2D5o for the regular model,
https://tinkercad.com/things/9QvmtPOAdhD for regular minimalist, https://tinkercad.com/things/9pyJxELLzPO for the sunk screw hole model, or https://tinkercad.com/things/e6ugwhoLcmk for minimalist sunk screw holes. Version history:
1.0 First try
2.0 Fix all the holes so they are in the right places, made the walls higher, so the measurement from the holes center to the edge is equal in both directions and according to specs, plus some cosmetic work.
3.0 Reworked most of the model to get more precise measurements, more air-holes, a more even hex-pattern, and to be easier and more modular to rework in the future.
3.1 Adjusted hole sizes, and removed one set of legacy holes.
3.2 Fixed some minor stuff that's been bothering me, and added the version with sunk screw holes, and the minimalist versions.

Use M3 screws for the small HDD or SSD in the adapter, and 6-32 UNC 2B screws for the adapter in the 3.5" slot or drive-bay. The adapter will fit in the drive-bay in any orientation, such as upside down, backwards and both at the same time.
The drive will fit in the adapter both forward-facing and backwards, aligned to the right, left, or middle, as well as placed some ways back.
If you are planning on mounting the 2.5" drive "inside" the adapter, consider printing the version with sunk screw holes This is a fairly large print, and I suspect it would warp badly if printed in ABS.

comments.text:
Any slicer will have problem generating 3 lines of walls when printing with 0.4mm nozzle (standard)
You could just run 4 parallel beams across instead of all these holes and get even better structural support.
CURA has its on issues printing multiple perimeters. I was recommending it to everyone until i discovered craftware.
Only craftware retracts each time before starting to print another perimeter. Cura just slides to the next causing bad initial contact (nozzle gets wiped and filament pulled out during travel). It can be fixed by disabling combing, but it will retract so much it will make you want to trash your printer.
I brought up the issue many times, they have yet seriously considered it.

This is a device that helps keep your iPod headphone cord neat and tidy when you're not using it. I kept finding my cords getting pulled or damaged in my bag. I would wrap the cord around my iPod when i put it into my bag, but when I pulled it out it was always a mess! So i made a prototype out of plastic. [The prototype is acrylic, only about 1/8" thick. My design calls for a 3/4" thick plastic piece because this would prevent the wire from getting damaged due to bending. It would be nice if I had a 3D printer to make it.]
All you have to do is put your headphones into the spots on the main panel, then start wrapping the wires around the notches on the sides. When you get to the end, just tuck the jack underneath the wrapped wire and presto... neat and tidy into your bag/coat/purse... STILL neat and tidy when you pull it out again!
I do need to give credit to my dad, since he gave me the basic idea for the wrapping and the notches. However I have expanded on his idea with the indents where the headphones can fit.

You don't have to make the exact design I have here. Any old piece of plastic with some notches [sanded down of course] will work fine.
If you want you can drill a hole for a key ring in one of the corners.
My first 3D Model.

title: Light Diffuser for Mr. Beams Motion Light

description.text:
The default diffuser is just a plastic panel; it has a harsh and inefficient pattern for general light. It was really intended to light a foot-path, but I wanted generally diffuse light. This diffuser spreads light a bit more evenly. Model MB720, like this on Amazon:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002FCGI8Y/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 I included the 123dx source so you can remix easily. I was thinking to try meshmix with those twisty vases they featured on Thingiverse's main page.
Build it out of translucent plastic; I used natural PLA.  You can use translucent colors, too.  It's thin; give it one shell and 100% fill.

author: minhminh

description.text:
I made this simple but effective stand because I couldn't find one on Thingiverse that supports tablets at more than one angle. This stand will hold an ipad or other tablet with or without a case (up to 1/3 inch thick), in the vertical or horizontal position at either ~38 or ~68  degrees from the horizontal. 
If someone has any tips or suggestion to improve this design please let me know...

The cross section piece is slightly large to allow for a tight fit. Some filing and or sanding may be needed to make the pieces fit. I was able to get a good fit within a few minutes using a hand file. There is now a new version with holes to save plastic and weight. I have not tested it!
All parts ending in "lite" are from the new version. If your printer can print multiple parts at a time use_Ipad_Stand.stl or Ipad_Stand_lite.stl Otherwise you'll need to print Ipad_Stand_Cross_lite.stl and two of Ipad_Stand_Side_lite.stl
There's also a wider cross piece called Ipad_Stand_Cross_wide+lite.stl I made it because I think that the first stand was a bit narrow.

title: Micro Quadcopter R2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This micro quadcopter is 3D printed with ABS plastic parts. The arms are capable of bending without fracturing under a heavy impact, yet they are rigid under a normal load. These attributes are perfect for a micro multicopter frame. Kits and parts are available for purchase from my website:
http://polakiumengineering.com/?page_id=1989

The primary required components (not included) are as follows:
  • Turnigy 2900KV Brushless Outrunner
  • Turnigy Plush 6A ESCs
  • 5030 Props
  • 5030R Props
  • 1000mAh 2S NanoTech LiPo
  • KK2 Flight Controller or similar (45mm hole spacing)
    • Detailed build instructions can be found here:
    http://polakiumengineering.com/?page_id=1989 If you like my design, please consider donating or purchasing a kit from my website.

I designed, and printed this upholstery attachment for a 1 1/4" shop vac hose.
I own the shop vac, but lost all the attachments years ago.  Late on a Saturday evening I thought it would be easier to vacuum the van with the right attachment vs just the bare hose end.  I designed the attachment in Sketchup, more as a  challenge to see if a) I could b) it would print and c) would it work.
The pictures show more than a thousand words.

After using this to clean out the minivan, I discovered a few area that I could change to make this thing better. But the van is now clean, and I will not need to vacuum again for some time. I will leave it to you to modify this part to make it more structural where the hose joins the base (mine broke there) and it would work better if the whole unit was angled 45 degrees. I printed this thing at 30% infill and .25mm layer height.
  • Print
  • Clean up print
  • Vacumm
  • Profit???

Allows you to adjust the tension on your y-axis belt by turning screws.

1) Print the casing, insert and pin.
2) You'll need to drill two new holes on the print bed about 12mm outside the two holes that are already there for the belt retainer.  I found it was easiest to just clamp the casing into position and then drill up from underneath.  Make sure that the belt pass-through hole is aligned with the belt retainer in the rear so that the belt runs in a straight line laterally.
3) Once you have the holes drilled, mount the casing using the two screws from the belt retainer that came with the kit.
3) Run the belt through the casing and mark where the belt comes to when pulled tight, inside the casing.  
4) Remove the belt from the far end belt retainer.
5) Run the belt through the center hole in the insert, loop it around the belt pin, and back out through the center hole in the insert.  
6) Make sure that the point you marked on the belt is on the inside edge of the insert, pull the belt tight around the belt pin and secure with a zip tie.
7) Run two 6-32 screws through the two adjustment holes on the insert and install hex nuts.  You may want to tighten the nuts down so they seat in the hex inlays in the insert.  (I tacked mine in with a bit of CA glue.)  Set the screws so that they're flush with the hex nuts on the inside side of the insert.
8) Pull the belt through the back hole of the casing to bring the insert into the casing.  The insert should rest flush with the back inside face of the casing.
9) Re-attach the belt to the far end belt retainer and secure with a zip tie.  Make sure it is snug but not too tight.
10) Adjust the belt tightness by turning in the adjustment screws on the forward face of the insert.  Test the tightness as you adjust the screws to get the right amount of tension.  You want it to be nice and snug, but not so tight as to strain the components or to cause the Y-axis stepper motor to stall.

comments.text:
one and a half hour later... this thing needs a remix. As others have
posted it sits too far up and that angles the belt. This will at some
point lead to critical belt failure due to it being sanded down. It's
installed and it works, but I had to do some serious filing and
shimming.
comments.author: Eirinn

comments.text: Yeah, I eventually added some washers in there to move it into alignment.  I did that when I upgraded my belts and pulleys.
comments.author: Eirinn

comments.text: Also the wall is too thin, the screw wanted to poke out of it, but that was probably due to my 0.1 infill more than anything else. The ultimaker is nice and I'll probably get one, one day, but for now it's too expensive. And my PB Plus is producing some pretty decent prints.
comments.author: rickmellor

comments.text: This thing is the best, I did have to add 4 washers on each side to set it at the right level on my PB+.  I'm going to make your x-tensioner now!

comments.text: Nice part, but on my printbot it doesn't line up with the drive bearings.  It needed more thickness on top to push the belt down to line up with the bearings.  Because I found this out after printing I just shimmed it with a 1/8" piece of lexan I had around.

title: Prusa Style X Ends and Action68 style 1(almost) piece extruder

description.text:
My style of extruder, and the x ends to go with it...
Features: Extruder snaps right onto the LMU's, Idler uses no bolt hinge. X-Ends are very light and snap onto LMUE's(long ones).

Print all parts with supports enabled.
You will need zip-ties for stabilisation. The Bl files are agains backlash on the x-ends.
The opto x probe is mounted throught the tiny slit in the extruder.
The opto holder snaps onto the smooth rods..
Video of a print a look at the parts: http://youtu.be/plarvTh5lnM
Photos follow very soon.

title: GoPro Mount for paintball (22mm 0.86'' diameter)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EASY TO PRINT and NO EXTRA TOOLS NEEDS  
This is a mount I use to attach my GoPro camera to my paintball gun's barrel. The barrel has (outside) diameter 22mm (0.86inch).  
The mount is design the way you do not need any support while printing - that's why corners are flat, not curved. Wholes and free space are a little bit bigger then in original GP mounts, to be sure everything goes smoothly. There are also holes for zip/cable tie (polski: trytytka ;) for additional protection for the GoPro.  
If you think It is usefull or there should be some changes, leave your opinion in comments.

My instrucions are just demonstrative and they can be freely changed. To print my GoPro mount I use a PLA. The PLA is a good choice becouse the mount can be (a little bit) modify even after you print it. For example: 3D printer printed too tight/small mount and it cannot fit on tube/barrel, so you boil water and put the mount (just the end) to this hot water for couple seconds. Next, you pull the mount out of water and spread it (a little bit) by your hands. During the plastic (PLA) is warm, the mount can be strech and squeeze. I print it with 20% density - good enough to not break.
Honeycomb pattern inside.
Three (3) perimiters - just incase.
Layer height: 0.2 mm (with 150% first layer)
Default extrusion width 0.35 mm
Nozzel 0.4 mm

Basically this is a small quad frame to look somewhat like a Flyduino Warthox. http://flyduino.net/Quadrocopter-CF-Frame-Set-18cm-arm I have the original too, interestingly, I pritned with 40% filling and 3 layers of wall top, down and parameter, it weighs less than half the original frame weight and is strong enough to fly nice and take on minor crashes. Though not as strong as the carbon fiber original. Print this before ordering the original to see how your quad will fly, the orignal is 99 Euro, this is practically free. Update: The original arms were 6mm thick just like the original warthox frame arm, but the printed ABS arm was flexible at this thickness, this caused the arms to bend/flex during flight and the control board would go crazy crashing the quad. The update has 12mm thick arms, these work great and by weight they are still the exact same weight (20g) at twice the thickness compared to the warthox frame arm, printed with 40% rectilinear fill. Update 2: This has been flying amazing, much better than my DJI x450 frame based quad. With PI settings on KK2.0 board bumped to 100, its control is razor sharp.

  • 4000mah 3S

  • KK2.0 with 1.6a firmware

  • 8x4.5 carbon fiber props for DJI Phantom I got off ebay.
    • With all the above + the printed frame, this weighs 800grams and lots of fly time

A Makerbot Giveaway entry.
The next best thing to Link's Ocarina is Pan's Pipes!
Print one to take to your next bacchanalia!

• Slice PanPipes6.stl in skeinforge. A fill of 0.9 is suggested to eliminate air leakage. The other file, PanPipes6Up.stl, is not required; it's just to show the pipes in their playable orientation.

  • Print PanPipes6.stl.

  • Once printed, remove the plastic strings inside the pipes with a drill bit [not in a drill!] and sand interior walls smooth with sandpaper.

  • Play!
    • Want to change what you hear? Tweak the settings in the PanPipes.scad file using OpenSCAD!
    To do so, you will need Catarina Mota's excellent shapes.scad file: http://svn.clifford.at/openscad/trunk/libraries/shapes.scad

description.text:
This allows you to connect two ends of an ANSI MXL sized timing belt together. You can use this to take a length of belt and turn it into a loop.
It's designed to fit very snugly on the belt, so you may need to use a small flathead screwdriver to push the belt into the coupler. It provides a very solid joint.
It would be nice to make this parametric in OpenSCAD. I needed to knock something out quickly for a robotics project, so I did this in SolidWorks as seen in the attached .sldpart file.

I printed this on my Replicator sliced at 0.25mm layer height. I got the most consistent results when I oriented the model so the open side (the side you press the belt into) was facing up. I normally print raftless, but in this orientation there is very little surface area in contact with the HBP, which was giving me some issues. I had much better success once I printed with a raft.

If you have an old Porsche 944, and have had the misfortune of having to replace the windshield washer motor, or have been avoiding it because the replacement washer pump costs $100+, then this thing might just do the trick.  This lets you attach a Camaro washer pump (Advance Auto Parts # 172650) to the factory VDO pump bracket.

I printed this in ABS with .2mm slicing at 225 C. Slic3r's brim prevented any curling, and the results are fantastic. The completed part can mount using 3x8mm machine screws or slightly longer 3x12mm screws - bolts won't fit on all the points, but then, that's what thread locker is for. The pump itself is both taped (with super-heavy duty duct tape) as well as anchored with two nylock ties. I've published more details on my blog at:
http://piratefish.blogspot.com/2012/09/3d-printing-for-porsche-parts.html

Raspberry Pi, submerged! *** PLEASE NOTE - THIS IS NOT IN WATER!!! Do not try this without the proper materials and knowledge! Please share if you make one or something like it, I would love to see what others do! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dKA2PLR_kp4

*** PLEASE NOTE - THIS IS NOT IN WATER!!! Do not try this without the proper materials and knowledge! This is using a standard round 3 gallon fish tank from Walmart.
3 Gallons of Animal grade Mineral Oil (Mineral oil is non-conductive and widely used in Power pole transformers) I adapted the filter base that came with the tank and removed the 1 1/4 inch up tube from the center. Then fabricated the Raspberry Pi stand to attach to the hidden filter base. The stand has a center hole up the shaft so you can run the tubing needed for the bubble effect. Side Note: The Raspberry Pi SD card slot must have a tight fit and we had to start over a couple of times due to the card coming loose and the card being fouled to where it would not boot. ** Personal Note: We have been working and experimenting with mineral oil for several years now. Its not for the timid. It is messy and if one thing goes wrong, you have to painstakingly remove the oil and let the device drip for several days.
In the past, we have submerged full computers and a couple of XBox 360's!

The wifi signal is almost nothing. Unless the wireless router is sitting within 5 feet, it won't see it. I used a USB based Wifi adapter with extension and ran it external of the oil, worked like a charm.

comments.text:
might want to remind people that you cant just throw an electronic device into a jug of water...
Folks: you have to make sure you use a clean, non-conductive oil if you are doing a submerged device. NOT WATER!
This kills the rPi.
comments.author: bobnojio

comments.text:
It's a good thing you want to prevent others from trying this with water. But IMHO, I think your concern "should be" unnecessary here, as this is thingiverse, not instructables or a site for some redneck DIY. The people visiting this website wouldn't just look at some pictures and try to replicate without proper research or reading through other resources on the matter - or atleast I hope so.
And last but not least... I hope someone actually tries to submerge his/her RPi in water just because he/she saw it on the pictures, and fries the RPi. This would be a small sacrifice for a life lesson. Maybe even prevent this individual from winning a Darwin Award in his/her future. ;)
comments.author: bobnojio

comments.text: Haha thats a risk of thingiverse or instructables or whatnot though.    theres always going to be SOMEONE who is dumb enough to try.
comments.author: NoPinky

comments.text: Actually DISTILLED water is non-conductive. It's the impurities in water that conduct... I used to use distilled water as an electrical coolant all the time, and it was a COMMON coolant used for cooling the first mainframes.
comments.author: bobnojio

comments.text:
Guess what happens when dust lands on an RPI, and the RPI then gets submerged. Impurities.
Use mineral oil, don't even use distilled water.
comments.author: DasWookie

comments.text:
yes, but Distilled water isnt what people think of when you say Water.
you clearly understood exactly what I meant :D dont just throw electronics in TAPwater.

The Ijen Volcanic Complex is a group of stratovolcanoes on East Java, Indonesia. The main caldera in which the volcanoes sit is 20 kilometers wide. The lake in the center of the caldera is recognized as the largest highly acidic lake in the world with a pH of 0.5 due to the presence of sulfuric acid. This model has a VE of 3 due to the large surface area. High Elevation: 3200m
Low Elevation: 0m
Area: 2,116 km2

author: HeAdWaVe

description.text:
Made three AK type flash hiders for airsoft. Also made notched versions if it's required. Added threaded spacer to hide threads on the external barrel if they are too long. Print with standard .2 supports are not required.  
Update: Added new flash hiders that can fit 24mm positive thread. Version 1 has the threads right at the edge and version 2 has the threads recessed inside. Just uploaded the 14mm neg to 24mm pos thread adapter. If you import the stl file into makerware make sure to turn the adapter upside down or it will not print properly. Included the thing file with it already upside down .Also print with 3-4 shells the 2 shell didn't stand up to the pliers very well. Planning on releasing the second type ak flash hider with 24mm thread soon.

comments.text: Hi, i'm starting in this 3d printing thing, do you recommend to print the flash hiders vertically or just horizontally without support? I ask you because of the overhanging parts, and i don't know if it would need support or not. Cool models btw.
comments.author: Charlieline

comments.text: Haven't printed this yet but I'm guessing standing up. Usually if the overhangs aren't too crazy it's likely that your printer can handle the overhangs. Try and guess which way is the best for a print. Since it has threads you probably don't want to print this lying on the side. Cylindrical stuff like this will need supports lying down and won't look nearly as nice because how the cylinder gets printed. Standing up, the printer can just go in circles. Another thing, you may need a raft, the surface area touching the plate will not be much. Practice  and eventually you can figure these things out yourself :)
comments.author: Charlieline

HELLBOY LOGO

I thought the jigs in thing # 53316 were a bit too complex, so I believe I came up with a way to use a slightly modified version of one of the original separate jigs in the original thing. Cheaper and quicker to print everything by using one simpler jig instead the two. You follow everything there (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53316), except use THIS MINOR modification of one of the original jigs for both the shaping step (do NOT mount the advancer wheel) and the drill step (with the advancer wheel put back in). You also will only need a single shorter bolt (around 3" 1/4-20) which you probably need to drill in a "divot" in the end as is shown in the video when he describes the original drill guide. 5/1/14: Rev 2 - sized the block better for the standard 1/4-20 3 1/4" bolt, and added a pair of spots in the top to hold the cap nut in the case you want to drill with a Dremel Drill Press converter stand instead of mounting a drill to a table.. 5/6/14 Rev 3 - discovered the site I used to size the top cap nut holders was wrong. Updated to enlarge the nut holders to match actual nut sizes.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/b2AYk3WEqst

Follow instructions and video at original thing #53316!  He did a GREAT job, just over thought the tools.  
I tried to use carbide #80 bits to drill stainless steel cap nuts but the SS is too hard and teh carbide too brittle and I shattered all that I bought.  So the instructions call out for High Speed Steel (HSS) bits and those will probably work better.  I also have ordered the softer brass nuts now and I hope that makes a big difference.  
Also, do NOT forget to lubricate when drilling- WD40 would work great.  
If you are using the cap nut holders in the top of my redo of the jig, it is designed to hold the cap nut upright to drill from the top, or cap down to drill from the inside as the milled nuts seem to have a machined in cone that will tend to autocenter the drill bit and act to hold the bit from skidding around.  Good luck with the drilling- I hope to be successful soon.

description.text: HELLBOY LOGO BAS-RELIEF

A Makerbot Giveaway entry. This is a stereoscope used for viewing stereo pairs (two images that together make a 3D image) arranged parallel style (not cross-eye). Thanks to its central pivot, it can be used with a wide variety of image sizes. It's ideal for viewing pairs made of two 5x7" photo prints, or images approximately that size on a monitor. It's also fun to just plain look through the viewer, because it increases your depth perception by effectively moving your eyes farther apart. But that's only half the fun. I've included a collection of stereo images I made especially for this viewer (see "Kongoscope_3D_Image_Funpack.pdf").
They're good viewing on your monitor or printed on 8.5 x 11" paper. But that's not all! I wrote a light-hearted user manual (see "Kongoscope_USER_MANUAL.pdf") that should make assembly easy and fun. It also has viewing tips. While writing the manual, I made up a fantasy company, KONGO!, that's marketing this device. See their comic book advertising over there on the left. I hope somebody has fun with this! EDIT OCT. 6, 2010: By request, I've added the original Blender file. Note that there are reference objects in the file not meant to be printed, like mirrors and screws.

All the instructions you need can be found in the file Kongoscope_USER_MANUAL.pdf. It also contains the parts list and a fair amount of goofiness. Here are a couple sources for the mirror you will need:
http://www.frontsurfacemirror.com/3mmMirror.htm
http://scientificsonline.com/product.asp_Q_pn_E_3052324 If anyone knows of other retailers of reasonably prices first surface mirror, please add links below! Thanks!

title: Drawer With a Secret
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small box with a drawer and a secret compartment.  
I've included the top with the 'C' inlay but I've also included a blank top STL and STEP file so you can customize it with your own inlay.  
The idea is not mine but I thought it would make a nice 3D printing project.

Print MainBoxBottom and MainBoxTop and glue together.  
Print Drawer and Handle and glue together.  
If using the inlay then print and glue into the top.  
Print out the FeltTemplate at 100%. Roughly cut out and pin to some flet. Cut out the shape in felt and glue into the bottom of the box. superglue glues PLA and felt together.

title: Rotary Engine Geared Rotor Keychain - with Arched Text

description.text: This design was derived from the Wankel Rotor at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13406 and added the rotated text from the "Bre Pettis OpenSCAD Medal - Now with Text" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9034 . An upright bass with a stand to give as gift to musicians.

Printed these with ABS 3mm using a .35mm nozzle. The bass was printed with 50mm/s and 25% infill, but its possible to put less infill and make it faster. The stand was printed with 65mm/s and 5% infill. It has 9.5cm of height, which was as high as my printer would go, so be sure to scale as needed.
Also the stand was printed 5% larger than the actual size, so that the bass would fit nicely in it.
You can put the name of the person you want to give this to on the stand, just like I did. It may be better if you make your own adjustments to the strings since it was really difficult to print these without falling apart. All pieces that are printed apart were glued with acetone.

This 3D printed single pickup allows you to customize guitar sound.
By choosing the length of copper wire for a coil in pickup you steer with resistance and this influences your sound. Work is still in progress, for now we have pickup with 0,06 mm copper wire and 6,8 kohm resistance. This value gives more severe sound than common Fender pickups which have 5,8-6,2 kohm resisatnace. You can hear how it sounds here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0vnK9ZAWGBs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PrhiiQw6HPc Making of this pickup:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9-xlyxviJ_Y&src_vid=PrhiiQw6HPc&feature=iv&annotation_id=annotation_2770987491 This is my friend's idea who is guitarist. He also created these 3d models. If you want to hear more of his music check:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-oUkevg1yatkoDmL0KMm3g

You will need:
  • 3 printed parts
  • spool of 0,06 mm copper wire
  • 5x15 mm AlNiCo5 magnets (alternatively 5x18mm)
  • natural wax
  • two electrical wires to connect it
    • Print all the parts, insert 5x15mm AlNiCo5 magnets and create a coil with the resistance at least 5,5 kohm.
    There are many movies on internet showing how to create a coil, we used low budget method where we used a drill.
    Solder electrical wires to two copper wire endings. Remember to remove a insulation from copper wire in the place where you solder it. You can use a source of heat for this. Heat blower will do the job. Lighter is not very good because it will burn the wires.
    When it is done take some pot and melt natural wax in it. Do not exceed your polymer melting temperature! So when you reach 60 - 70 degrees, immerse your whole pickup for 20 mins.
    After this leave pickup for cool down. Insert the cover. Your pickup is ready to mount on a guitar :)

title: SiLabs compatible ESC circuit flash tool

description.text:
This is more of an idea than instruction how to do it and doubt that no one will print this :) Faced with dilemma; how to flash 9+ SiLabs ESCs with minimal work. Flash pads are O ?1mm 1.5mm apart so normal spaced contactors won't do.
For a self-made flash tool, spring loaded contactors are a must (and I really really wanted them) so search began.
Finally found suitable, sony ericsson Z600 SMC battery contactors. They are 2-1-2 and 2 are damn near that 1.5mm but the middle 1 was not -> saw that %#&!er off and glue it closer -> DONE Why I expect this to work for most ESCs, is that it's said that the pads are near always at same order.. (https://github.com/bitdump/BLHeli/blob/master/SiLabs/BLHeli%20supported%20SiLabs%20ESCs.pdf) Other than that the build is pretty straight forward, two 3mm bolts (I used 3x10 flat with washers) to hold it together and space around provided to route the wires. I used normal servo extender leads (tip: cut one in half) but others can be used. The end contactor slot provided 7.6mm x 2.5mm x 2mm Links for the rest of the project: http://oddcopter.com/2012/07/18/flashing-silabs-escs-with-blheli-firmware/ the main link with links to the latters inside.. http://www.olliw.eu/2012/owsilprog-tutorials/ https://github.com/bitdump/BLHeli/tree/master/SiLabs/Hex%20files

title: Thumb adjustable z-axis microswitch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Spring-loaded sliding mount for a good old mechanical micro switch. Has about 6mm of travel (1/4") so get it close then fine tune the deck height.
This works really well and is a nice example of close tolerance sliding parts printed in PLA.
Found these cheap and nasty micro switches on fleabay for a few cents each. http://www.ebay.com/itm/261071015810

Print it out - one file does the three parts.
3 perimeters, 3 layers, 0.35 nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, 25% infill at 90 degrees fill angle.
Fit an M3 nut to the hole in the thumbwheel - would be a press fit but if it resists just push it in with a hot soldering iron. Run a long M3 screw through the thumb wheel and tighten it against the nut.
Find a suitable spring - I used on from a ball point pen - shorten it to fit in under compression, about 25mm or 1".
Fit another M3 nut in the top of the fixed part then assemble it like the photo.
Fit it to the smooth rod below the z axis below the lowest point of travel.

description.text:
hello, this is a model of the LV-T30 rocket engine from the game Kerbal Space Program. 
I modelled it in sketchup, it a high quality model because i used 100 sides in a circle instead of the regular 24.  
its base is about 74mm in diameter and it stands about 102mm tall.

I will print it as soon as I get my Rostock Max back online, waiting new bowden clamps to arrive  
I hope you like it.

This is a clip and simple mount for a FreeTrack Project based headset clip.
The Clip is designed around 5mm cubed IR LEDs I've sourced from used equipment. I see no reason normal IR LEDs could not be used though.
Wire channels of 1mm depth are part of the design along with a relatively large central mounting point for alternative mounting methods and wiring.

• Print at least the Clip Model

  • Check Free-Track.net for simple assembly instructions and information on what LEDs to use plus more detailed wiring information.

  • I created the mount with a flat placement in mind and without through holes since I prefer to drill holes rather than let the printer make imperfect ones. It uses a M3 nut with a M3 x 8mm screw and washer for the swivel. The block is 24 x 25mm if you wish to make a different style block more suitible for your headset.
    • Note: I also use the 5 volts from a mini usb cable as you see in the completed image. This is neither ideal nor generally safe for the computer. I personally think I'll be ok but be Warned!

comments.text: Nice! A photo of it mounted would help alot for us new to the concept. There are alot of different configurations on http://Free-Track.netFree-Track.net

comments.text: I've uploaded a couple new images regarding my mounting setup. My headset is a little unusal in that it is flat. The mounting block is simply attached using double sided foam tape.

author: APUC

description.text:
Update 02010-05-18
New STL file uploaded: KeypadBoxV2.stl. Better tolerances so less clean up. 6mm taller so that bottom panel fits. Added instruction to replace straight header on keypad with right-angle one so that box can be lower-profile. Update 02010-05-06
New STL file uploaded, KeypadBox04.stl. Keypad opening in previous version, KeypadBox03.stl, was rotated 90Â°. :P A Makerbot Giveaway entry. Need a box for Revar's excellent LCD Display and Keypad mod? Here's a printable one! This is an experiment in using different $fn values in OpenSCAD to selectively control the "roughness" of the geometry on different parts. The $fn of the outside of the box is set to 3, while all the holes and openings are set to 60. This gives an overall edgy look to the part without sacrificing functional precision. I really like the ability to combine a lo-fi trash-punk look yet maintain precision where it's needed in a printable part. I will definitely be exploring this aesthetic further! More info on Revar's LCD mod: http://wiki.makerbot.com/revarlcd-assembly More info on OpenSCAD's $fn variable: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Other_Language_Features

Printing
  • Slice KeypadBoxV2.stl in skeinforge. The other file, KeypadBox04Up.stl is just to show the orientation of the piece in use.
  • Print KeypadBoxV2.stl.
  • Clean up strings and holes with knife and drill bits [no drill please!]
    • Assembly
  • Replace straight header on keypad with right-angle one. This requires un-/soldering header from PCB.
  • Feed one end of cable through slot and attach to keypad
  • Mount keypad in opening with M2 bolts and nuts
    • TODO
    Provide links for header, screws, and bolts.
    Upload STL for 1mm bottom panel.
    Upload STL for LCD box
    Update Assembly instructions to include connecting Keypad and LCD box.

comments.text: I laid it on its left side for printing. What slicer program are you using? I used Kisslicer and it was not noticeable slow not sure what would cause that. I may try to simplify the drawing a bit and see what happens.

comments.text:
I printed it on its back to avoid having to use supports for the parts that stick out, which causes a tad bit of unavoidable warning where the rounded corner is.
I'm using regular slic3r. but it isn't just the slicer that takes a while its importing it into repetier. i figure you just have it set to a really high resolution (isn't a problem, just noteworthy). for anyone who has slicer, if you set your resolution for this print to .01 instead of zero (full res), it will take 1/20th the time to slice and look exactly the same.

title: Raspberry Pi Case / Cover for Model B - One-piece design with snap-in clips

description.text:
This case fits the Raspberry Pi Model-B and prints as a single piece. I recommend printing with the top facing down. This design was borrowed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280051 I modified it to have pre-made holes for connectors and threw a Raspberry Pi logo on top. Two versions are included.
One with an extruded Raspberry Pi logo which will require extra support material and one with a logo that is flush with the top of the case. I've not test printed yet so I may have to make revisions.
Feel free to leave a comment if you have any questions.

author: lancealot

title: Picatinny rail mount for PPS 40mm Airsoft Grenade/Shower Shell

description.text: This is a picatinny rail mount made specifically to attach a PPS 40mm shower shell to a KWA ATP airsoft pistol but it should be appropriate for attaching most any 40mm accessory to a picatinny rail. I've included the .scad files for modifications, in particular you may want to resize the top portion to accommodate whatever you intend to use it on.
This was printed on a Solidoodle 2 with a small raft, brim, and skirt lying flat on its side. It should not be necessary to print support material for the screw holes, but your mileage may vary.

comments.text: Not that everything that is on here needs a purpose, but why exactly would I want to clip my grenade onto the front of my pistol?  Are you planning on firing the BB shower from there?  ACtually it probably wouldn't be very hard to 3d print a launcher.. someone should do that.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I actually designed this as a "minimalist" option for my main airsoft rifle because most of the other options on the market are both expensive and heavy. I mounted it to a KWA ATP in the picture because I thought it was amusingly absurd.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I've been telling myself to model a launcher for the past few years now, but still haven't gotten around to it.  I mean, all the airsoft grenade launchers really do is push a button on the grenade.  You could probably print a fully functioning launcher for ~10$ (hardware included), which would be nice considering most launchers are 75$+.  The only real downside would be that it's plastic (but then again that means less weight to carry around.)
comments.author: IVIUPPET

title: [V8.0] One/Two-Up Extruder with lever and adjustable tension (E3D support!)

description.text:
IMPORTANT
The current version only allows for mounting with the lever to the left of the stepper motor and drive gear. If you would like to make your extruder with the lever to the right, you an either message me and I will upload those files or you can mirror both main frame pieces along either the x or the y axis and it will work. Additionally, people have reported that when this extrder is printed in pla, it is not resistant enough to print at ABS temperatures. If you print the extruder and fan bracket in abs, it should be resistant enough to support abs printing. Also, I would highly recommend printing the fan bracket and running your fan at a minimum of 50% at all times. This will extend the life of your extruder. So I can't think of some clever name for the extruder, but hopefully the features make up for it! This extruder is designed for easy loading, easy adjustment, and reliable prints. Features
-Secure hot end clamping design
-Lightweight and low material usage (<30 cm3)
-Symmetrical (can be mirrored and mounted the other way)
-Lever for easy loading
-Filament guides for easy loading
-Adjustable tension via screw
-Uses stock spring, bearing, stepper/hobbed bolt, and long bolts
-Fan bracket
-New model with E3D hot end support! Requires
-2x m3 by 10mm bolts
-2x m3 by 20mm bolt
-1x m3 hex nut
-1x m3 by 45mm bolt (optional, to use as forth screw to mount stepper) See the Extruder on YouTube here!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PxeiYq2xyZw
How to put it together
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5pQ88_X9Tzw

Print 1 of each piece, and 1 of each desired body. One set is stock for the anubis hot end, and the ones with the E3D are for E3D hot ends. Regardless, you should print a total of 2 normal pieces, 2 reverse pieces, and a small slider piece. To assemble:
Place the bearing on the peg inbetween the two lever pieces. Use a m3x10mm bolt to connect the two pieces.
Place the spring in the cylindrical groove, and the hex nut in the spot just above it. Put the tension slider piece on the end of the spring on the end closer to the hex nut. NOTE the tensioner slider piece can be replaced with an M3x10mm or shorter socket cap bolt. Just put the length of the bolt into the spring and the end of the M3x20mm bolt will press against the head of the smaller bold that is set in the spring.
Now, put the lever arm in the large opening and make sure the spring goes in the small indent of the lever arm. The bearing should be near the hole in the main frame piece.
Put the hot end in the groove and then slide the long screws through. You do not need to put a screw through the top right screw hole (the top one that the lever doesnt go on).
Use the wood frame pieces as a spacer between the extruder and the stepper. See picture for more details.
Assembly picture courtesy of defendor!

comments.text: has anybody  else hadd the problem of the otside of prints having gaps
comments.author: LivingLayered

comments.text: This gave me a real hard time. I dremeled a hole in the side for troubleshooting. As it turns out Q3d changed to a new steel filament drive gear that is a lot smaller. I had to do a lot of modifications to get it to feed. It does hold the e3d much better thank you.
comments.author: hobbesman715

comments.text: I liked the design at first but I've now decided to stay away from this.
comments.author: Mortimer452

comments.text: I use the extruder designed for the Anubis to mount the Prometheus hot end and that has worked wonderfully.  I never could get the plastic slider to work and made one out of aluminum.  Biggest problem is that I had to fight with the Anubis to print out this extruder frame and the upgrade parts needed to mount the Prometheus.  For a while it didn't look like I could get there from here.
comments.author: Mortimer452

comments.text: Thanks for your feedback. I'm aware that not having a view port can be troublesome for troubleshooting, but some people have done some remixes which include a view port and also I believe one with a fan duct to cool the inside of the extruder. Additioanlly, people have had more success using a m3x10mm bolt in place of the tensioner slider. Hopefully this helps you if you decide to go back and anyone else with the same concerns.
comments.author: Mortimer452

comments.text: This thing has a major glitch. One thing is that it's completely enclosed. So if something gets jammed you have to kill your print and take apart the extruder to fix it. Every so often, I think because of lack of ventilation, it gets too hot inside the extruder assembly and the filament will soften to the point of bending. Once that happens the thing just keeps on feeding, giving a coiled snake of damn near unremovable mess that ruins the print.
comments.author: collegefishies

comments.text: Excellent and simple design. Works like a champ.
comments.author: ulmeck

comments.text: How do I get the filament to load easily? When I try to do it it always misses the hot end.
comments.author: Parizival

comments.text: Does anyone else experience wobble with the e3d version? If not then maybe I need to print a new one with the e3d now that I have it mounted. XD
comments.author: reluttr

comments.text:
SOLVED:
Found it. Change the configuration.h file. Under the // Red Printrboard section change the definition for "INVERT_E0_DIR" mine was set to true so I flipped it to false.

comments.text: I should have said I need the STEP files for the anubis version... I see you have uploaded the E3d version already. Thank you.
comments.author: rocketsguy

I was wondering if it would be possible to get the parts as STEP files? I would like to make some modifications in the future and I don't have access to solid works. Thank you for designing this, and making it available.
comments.author: rocketsguy

comments.text: Does the E3D hotend mount is compatible with JHEAD hot end, I have one here for a new printer that I try to print but since the print from QU-BD HOTEND are crap, I need to use something different
comments.author: labidus

comments.text: I believe the e3d uses a j-head mounting groove so both theoretically should fit into this e3d extruder.
comments.author: labidus

comments.text: I also have another question, I need to use a mirrored version, but the fan bracket on the left side, it will have space? it will not touch the treaded rod?
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: I would recommend printing it how I have with the fan bracket on the right hand side and just change the firmware. It is easy enough and it is good to know how to upload new firmware to your board in case you would ever like to add enstops or upgrade your printer majorly.
comments.author: labidus

comments.text: thanks, I will try to print this and hopefully be able to have a piece of plastic that is usable with my crappy printer lol
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: I suppose this can't be printed in PLA as it would melt in the part in contact with the hot end, right?
comments.author: BRAINDISIS

comments.text: PLA is fine with the e3d hot end, but if you print it in pla for the anubis hot end it is required to use the fan bracket as well. Also, people reported that printing abs with this extruder printed in pla will not go well, even if you have the fan blowing on the top of the hot end.
comments.author: BRAINDISIS

comments.text:
How'd you wire the fans with the e3d? Are both controlled by the board simultaneously or is one on all the time?
And isn't the duct that blows on the heat break unnecessary?
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: Sorry for the very late response. The fan for the e3d should be powered directly by the power supply so it is always on at full speed. And the duct is not required or even possible to use with the e3d version, only for the anubis version.
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: The V7.0 lever arm seems to be too wide to fit in the extruder body. There's a 1mm gap between the halves of the casing when holding all the pieces together.
comments.author: SleepersTide

comments.text: That's odd. If you can, measure how tall each of your extruder body halves are. They should be 12mm thick exactly. It kind of sounds like something got messed up with your print causing it to squish a little, I've seen this happen quite a number of times.
comments.author: SleepersTide

comments.text: Has any one had trouble slicing the levers? For some reason my slicer is not slicing the whole stl. Any suggestions?
comments.author: Minllar

comments.text: Quick question, what size motor is this made for?
comments.author: DocNasty

comments.text: Nema 17, any motor with a bolt hole distance of 31mm square will work
comments.author: DocNasty

comments.text: Any chance of tweaking it to accept a NEMA14?
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: The extruder stepper motor seems to turn the wrong way with this design, it was fine with the stock extruder. Any ideas?
comments.author: fin3rz

comments.text: Just built it now, very solid build and no more wobbling of the hotend, which is great.
comments.author: fin3rz

comments.text: A little bit of a problem, maybe it's just me. The real pictures show a narrow groove that fit into the collar of the hot end. The "thingview" shows a very wide collar that does not fit around my collar. Is that for a different type of hot end?

comments.text: Well there are 2 different models for 2 different hot ends.
comments.author: StuartW

comments.text: Thanks. Don't speak fluent 3D printer yet so I was seeing the newser v.6.2 when I should have seen E3D as a different type of hot end. Printing v 6.2 now... Or should I buy te E3D?
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: Ahhh right sorry I forgot they are different versions currently. I will update the versions so they are the same (apart from the e3d part) to avoid confusion.
comments.author: StuartW

comments.text: How would one slice the fan bracket? The best way is with the fan-interface lying onto the bed, but the round mounting point prevents it from being placed flat on the bed. I can't seem to find an easy way to slice it.
comments.author: JvdP

comments.text: The best way is to flip it 180* along the x or y axis (basically flip it upside down). I apologize I thought the part was oriented properly for printing. I will try to re-upload it soon!
comments.author: JvdP

comments.text: But then I supose you use support material?
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: Nope no support is needed. It will just bridge it across the top and you won't have a problem!
comments.author: JvdP

comments.text: Oh sweet you made a E3D version! I think it might be time for a extruder upgrade. ;)
comments.author: reluttr

comments.text: Exactly what I thought! I just don't want to spend $70+ on a new hot end...
comments.author: reluttr

comments.text:
thanks for the info.
Oh and, my tensioner slider just broke! think the print quality wasn´t good enough, but it doesn´t matter as I was able to replace it with a M3 x 10 screw.
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: That is actually a great idea! The same thing happened to me and I'm now using a screw as you suggested and it is much more reliable!
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: I just printed v6.0 and found out that you uploaded v7.0. Can you tell me what changed?
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: All that changed is the lever arm, and I would definitely recommend printing it as it is much stronger and more reliable. For future reference, you can tell which parts changed by looking at the part versions. The whole extruder version is simply the highest version of any part, but the parts may be different versions (like in this the frame is 6.1 and the lever is 7.0)
comments.author: Wilpe

comments.text: Very easy to load filament! Thank you! But I have a question: Is it possible to configure the stepper motor to reverse the direction? After this upgrade it moves the filament out instead of in the extruder :-/ I don't want to change the lever to the right side.
comments.author: tist

comments.text: It is possible to do so by re-uploading the firmware with adjusted parameters, but there is a much easier way to do it.
comments.author: tist

comments.text:
Ok wait...
The connector wires on mine are in this order, Green, Black, Blue, Red.
All I need to do is flip Blue and Red? Or do I need to flip blue and black, then green and red?
comments.author: DDeGonge888

comments.text: Yes just flip blue and red. And be sure everything is unpowered before you start pulling cables.

i designed this spindle to clip onto the edge of a wire shelf which my printer sits on top of. it should fit most spools with a center hole larger than 35mm and less than 10cm deep. holes run through the clip portion to allow zip ties to be threaded through for extra secure hold.  
i've uploaded a new version on the object to correct some issues with my own printout, strengthening the clips and enlarging the holes. in the original the clips were weak and could snap off, the temporary solution to which was just to drill some holes that i could use to tie it in place on my shelf
i printed mine from PLA with 40% infill and .3mm layer height. when done, run zip ties through the holes, install on a shelf and close the ties to ensure it stays put

In line with my desire for a 3D printer like the CupCake that uses conductive build material, here is a printable RC filter. The two spirals are a resistor and a capacitor. As you might have noticed, one of the spirals is continuous (the resistor) and the other has a gap in the center (the capacitor). Use of the circuit is just a matter of attaching power or a signal across the two thicker terminals perpendicular to the line formed by the spirals. This kind of circuit could probably be printed with traces on a PCB. Made in Inkscape and Blender. http://makezine.com/go/makerbot

This is a 2D design extruded so it has volume. The block underneath is just to support the thinner sections. Ideally, the block would be dielectric/plastic while the design on top would be conductive.

comments.text: 20% carbon black (by mass) into PLA (or PLC) yields a very conductive polymer (~0.09 Ohm/meter through 3mm filament), printed as an RLC resonant tank will be most interesting... any guess at this R(L)C behavior is suspect at best. Experimenters hoe!
comments.author: seedwire

comments.text: If you print it in copper R will be a fraction of an ohm and C will be only 10's of pF. That would give a time constant of the order of 1ps. At those sorts of frequencies the parasitic inductance and transition line effects would dominate.

description.text:
This is a functional ping pong balls launcher designed to be controlled by an arduino (or any other microcontroller). It uses a servo to dispense the balls and two motors with wheels to give speed and shoot them. Videos:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3zeoNTXP-Yo
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aiz_cN2QWQ8 Intructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-controlled-Ping-Pong-Balls-Launcher/

In order to build this you will need the following material:
  • Two servos
  • Two motors
  • Two o-rings
  • Two hinges
  • Bolts
  • Spacers
  • Arduino (or any other micro-controller) and an h-bridge
  • Ping Pong Balls!
    • On the pictures you can see all the assembling steps. Have fun! My parts and everything I needed to make this project were provided by Artica - http://www.artica.cc/ Thanks guys!

Roxy Iris Box: The Iris Boxes provide a good example of what 3D Printing is capable of doing. Because of the way Iris Boxes open people find them fascinating. The Roxy Iris Box is a reverse engineered version of a previous Iris Box that appeared on WWW.ThingiVerse.Com. Specifically: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140048 It is a very nice design but because it only had .STL files for the box it isnÂt easy to modify it.
I wanted to make a number of changes to it. I wanted:
  • a thicker (and stronger) box.
  • The ability to put lettering on the leaves
  • to change the speed at which the leaves open (so they open easier)
  • change and simplify the way the door mechanism mounts to the box
    I borrowed very heavily from the previously mentioned design, but the source code is entirely rewritten and available as part of this ThingÂ. Whether you want to change the letters on the leaves or the number of leaves or the height of the box, it should all be easy to accomplish (because the source code is provided).
This is a pendant engraved with the Noble Team logo, "Noble Team," and one of my favorite quotes "Die? Didn't you know? Spartans never die."

title: Greg's Wade extruder for Graber i3

description.text:
Just a little remix of the original extruder.
The extruder was generated by the original file and added extra supports for easy printing, for everyone to have a good result.
The extruder generated is 5.1 version of original, for 1.75mm filament.
The small and large gears have been modified to use the shorter screw tractor. Was added in small gear a chamfer, avoiding the use of screws for fixation. In large gear was shortened fitting screw tractor. In both gears was made a smooth teeth.
Not notice the extruder used with gears, because I used a well-worn, only to exemplify.
Full source code included.

description.text: Top piece to improve the Semi-Auto Rubber Band Gun

I downloaded and printed the Semi-Auto Rubber Band Gun that was uploaded by MacGyver... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39404 Except i only printed the internal parts from his upload and i printed the Improved Ratched Wheel from this upload... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39464/#files And the rest of the gun i used this upload... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:122955/#files Protheus did an awesome job on making the parts split and keyed together for assembly, they printed out great! The only problem i had was the rubber bands would sometimes catch on the trigger catch or the ratchet wheel couldn't sit flat on the trigger catch because the edges of the rubber bands would get between them. So i designed this cap to go on the top of the gun, i just glued it on so the ratchet wheel just clears the back edge of my cap. When you pull the trigger the trigger catch hides up under the cap and the rubber band has a nicer path to travel and fly off. You can also see i made two slight grooves in the top for the rubber bands to sit in using a round file, i might model a new one with those grooves printed in. Its now totally reliable!

comments.author: btjernigan

description.text:
This thing is a 3D printed shoulder rig for DSLR cameras to help stabilize when shooting video.
I'm using the industry standard aluminum pipe size and spacing, so it should be possible to combine these printed parts with commercially available parts and/or rigs, though I have only tried that once with a part for a friends rig.
All the parts are designed in OpenSCAD and those source files are included below, in case you want to modify the parts to work with other pipes, differently sizes screw, etc.

To print a rig like the one on the picture, you will need to print:
  • - 1 pcs. camera_plate.stl
  • - 2 pcs. std_clamp_b.stl
  • - 2 pcs. dual_parallel_std_clamp_a.stl
  • - 1 pcs. std_clamp_handle_holder_30deg.stl
  • - 1 pcs. std_clamp_handle_guide_30deg.stl
  • - 1 pcs. std_clamp_handle_holder_-30deg.stl
  • - 1 pcs. std_clamp_handle_guide_-30deg.stl
  • - 1 pcs. shoulder_holder_160.stl go shoulder_sholder_320
  • - 2 pcs. shoulder_holder_bracket.stl
    • In addition to the parts on this thing, you will also need a bunch (16 pcs for the pictured rig) of these (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11848) little thumb screws by Habbycam. It's designed for 1/4 inch, but I'm using them with M6 without any major problems. You will also need some aluminum pipes. The main pipes have an outer diameter of 15mm and the two handle pieces have an outer diameter of 20mm. I have found that the fairly cheap ones in the local hardware store can vary in dimensions, but it's what I use in my rig. Some times you will need to trim the parts a little bit to fit the pipe, at other times you might need to adjust the drawings (via the OpenSCAD files) for fit your pipes. The foam handles are for a kids bike and also from the local hardware store. The foam shoulder pad is just a left over piece of foam that has been covered in nylon cloth and mounted in the shoulder piece with velcro. To put everything together you will also need some screws and nuts. I use M6 for everything except mounting of the Manfrotto sliding plate, that one is mounted with 4 pcs M4 screws and lock nuts. Screws needed:
  • - You will need an M6 hex screw for each thumbscrew. 4 pcs. in 40mm (for the shoulder holder and handles), 10 pcs. 30mm
  • - 4 pcs. countersunk M6 screws (to mount the camera plate
  • - 20 pcs. M6 nuts
  • - 4 pcs. M4 20mm screws with M4 lock nuts (for mounting the Manfrotto 357 plate)
    • I am using a MANFROTTO 357 SLIDING PLATE ADAPTOR to mount the camera, but if you don't want that or want to use a different quick release plate, I have added holes in the middle of the camera plate for a 1/4 inch screw (with thumbscrew) that mates with the camera tripod mount or quick release plate. In addition to the rig itself, I have also added a few parts to hold an audio recorder like the Zoom H4n (h4n_holder.stl and h4n_mounting_clamp.stl) and a little clip to hold the camera strap in case you use one of those (strap_clip.stl). The lasercut_parts.pdf file holds two designs for cutouts in 2mm corc. Those are intended to be glued onto the camera plate and the H4n holder, to help ensure a good grip without scratching the mounted equipment. When mounting the Manfrotto plate, you don't need this corc piece.

More soon.

Inspired by Van Alles Wat's interactive lampshade design project, this customizable design allows you to upload an image to engrave onto the surface of a cylinder. By default, the cylinder is shaped like an Ikea Lampan shade, but you can adjust its size and proportions, as well as the depth of the engraving and a few other settings. Works best with depth maps or designs drawn in black and white. Pixel values are translated to depth of relief, so dark pixels are deeply recessed and white pixels are not.

Default output is a solid model intended to be printed with no infill and no top (for a vase-like object) or no top and no bottom (for a lampshade). Tom Burtonwood has written a useful guide for doing this with Makerware. Alternatively, you can specify a fixed inner radius, for variable thickness walls - kind of like a vertical lithophane. Regular photographs might look good when backlit with these settings, but I haven't tried it yet. Give it a go!
Updated, 14 April 2014: added a border_offset option. If nonzero, borders are shaped like the ends of the image surface, simply offset the given amount. If zero, and by default, borders are circular.
The default "shark" design is based on this Wikimedia Commons image by Fred Hsu.
I printed the sharkshade.stl sample model at 0.3 scale in brown PLA on my Printrbot Simple. 0.15 mm layer height, 1 perimeter, no infill, no top or bottom layers.

This is a cannabis / tobacco pipe with a twist! Made of linear extrusions in OpenSCAD, the pipe has an hourglass shape with a small hole running down the middle as per usual for a straight pipe such as a chillum or a one-hit. It also, however, has holes in the weave at each end for letting aeration occur. Depending on how you load, light, and draw you will get different results i believe, though the device is untested. You can if you wish, purchase one at ShapeWays in glazed ceramic with the following url: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/CreatorLes Otherwise you can download the stl file and print or make one yourself. This would be a good project for wire art as well.

You have a good bit of creative freedom in designing your Twisty Pipe.  How open the holes are and what the overall shape is are well customized to give you plenty of control.  Be sure to try some shapes with detail and sides set low for quick changes, then crank them both up for a smooth result.  Leave sides at three or four for a triangular or square cross-section to each strand, etc.  
Note that this object must be made in a flame-proof material such as various metals, ceramic, or glass.

I created this alternate rod-end plug to suit locally sourced parts. The plug is designed for 10mm O.D, 8mm I.D.  aluminium tube. The plug end is 8mm, so it may need some very light sanding to fit an 8mm internal diameter tube.  
Use these exactly as you would the original part - but only if you need a plug rather than a cup.

Print slowly with layer height of .2, and 70% infill.   
Tap the bore on the cone end with an M3 tap and then connect to your desired ball end with a M3x20mm set screw or equivalent.  
Sand the plug end very slightly until it fits inside the tube tightly, then glue into your rod end with epoxy.

title: Printrbot LC and LC+: Y Bearing Guide for GT2 32 teeth pulleys

description.text:
Upgraded to the Gt2 32 teeth pulleys and only to realized they don't fit at all. Designed a new Y bearing guide that offsets the 608 bearings back a few to make everything fit. 
By all means, go for a 18 or 25 teeth instead, don't make the mistake we made!

Print
  • Y bearing guide
  • Y bearing roof
  • 4 x M3 10mm long
    • Important
    The M3 x 8mm bolts that came with the Printrbot won't reach the mounting holes so M3 10mm long bolts are needed. The inner diameter holes may come out smaller than sized either from shrinkage or Slic3r gcode making inner diameter holes .5mm smaller. Some sanding will fix that.

comments.text: I always wondered: do you see a better resolution with bigger pulley wheels as the "polygon effect" decreases?
comments.author: TakeItAndRun

comments.text: I made one of these things. it worked but i had to make a second one while i learned on the first. tips: gently sand down the bearing posts so the bearings fit easily. do not force the bearings when sizing because it can get stuck enough that trying to get it off will break the post. don't try and glue it back together. you have to carefully drill out all the holes slightly smaller than an M3 bolt diameter. then you have to work on the counter sunk holes for the cap heads. i had a mototool and rectangular burr so it was pretty easy. i used 16mm M3 to hold the bearing cap on. carefully screw them in slowly. if you mess up a base hole, you can just drill it out the size of the cap. ideally you want at least the two bolts under the bearings to be pressed into the counter sink. i think if you mess it up you should just reprint until you get it right. then, make another one just to be safe. its in now and it works great

remixed_from.author: ScribbleJ
remixed_from.title: Automatic Platform Leveling and Z Calibration made SUPER EASY

description.text: This uses a magnetic reed switch for a Z-max endstop on a Thing-o-matic Makerbot printer which allows Z-axis re-calibration before each print.

This modification allows a re-calibration of the Z-axis endstop before each print. It does not require any electrical connection between the print head and printing platform, nor does it need to have components near the print heads at all. The circuit is very simple and is a variant of Makerbot's own endstop -
http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:mechanical-endstop-1-2 and is connected to the Z-max input of the motherboard using a standard CDROM audio cable. Here the mechanical switch of the Makerbot style endstop is replaced by a reed switch connected between the red signal line (4) in the makerbot circuit diagram to the black ground line (2 and/or 3). An led with current load resistor was also used between white positive connection (1) with a 10k resistor ( I used two 5k in series which were to hand) connected to white positive connection (1) and red signal line (4) to hold the signal line high when the reed switch is open circuit. The 10k resistance stops the motherboard burning out as it would otherwise act as a short. I recyled an old reed switch holder I had as a spare to save time implementing. Be careful to work on this with the bot powered down to avoid shorting the white positive connection (1) to the black ground line (2 and/or 3) when wiring up as this is likely to daamge your motherboard even if it is a momentary short! The magnets used to trigger the reed switch were taken from a used sonicare toothbrush head as these a nice strong magnets and an old blanking plate was cut and slipped over the side of the Z stage and fitted under the bolt head. This allowed the magnet to be moved up or down to fine tune the setting for the Z max position. The calibration code below is similar to the excellent work by ScribbleJ in thing:7008. You will also need to disregard the warning about the reverse homing direction during Gcode checks just prior to printing. ( begin homing )
G162 Z F500 (home Z axis maximum)
G161 X Y F2500 (home XY axes minimum)
G92 X0 Y0 (set current position = 0)
G1 X60 Y60 (goto 60,60 Z test point)
G161 Z F500 (home z minimum)
G92 X60 Y60 Z0 ( Set Z axis minimum, compensate for x y displacement )
G1 Z40.0 F3300.0 (move to waiting position for z)
G1 X0 Y0 ( return to expected position for X Y )
M132 X Y Z A B (Recall stored home offsets for XYZAB axis) This works successfully on my Dualstrusion Thing-o-matic with the Titanium belt APB, which works especially well when used with the Avery Clear labels - Sticks like glue - prints only come off with a lot of effort! Updated with profiles for RepligatorG 0040 Sailfish - December 2012
Arbot.xml Now with amended tool indexes for Sailfish A/B reversal.

Static dissipative wand for discharging yourself to avoid nasty shocks in a low humidity environment.

I was getting zapped all the time at my new job, the floors here and my shoes must be quite a way apart on the triboelectric series. So, I built this discharge wand as a bit of a joke, but it is actually pretty handy, and doubles as test equipment. Extras required: 1x NE-2 neon bulb (5 mm OD)
1x 39kR 1/4 W resistor (not critical)
2x Brass caps (or copper tape, tube, etc) Print two body pieces, solder the resistor and NE-2 bulb in series. Place NE-2 bulb so it is visible through the hole in the wand wall. Fold wires over the ends and cut to length, then secure and assemble by pushing on the end-caps. OpenSCAD file is parametric to accomodate different geometries. I just happened to have two brass caps in the junkbox here that worked well, you can use copper tape, or pieces of brass tubing, or anything else conductive, spheres, whatever. The resistor value is not critical, the smaller it is the more of a chance that you'll feel the current pulse, larger values up to a meg or so will be fine. 10s to 100s of kR are ideal for seeing the flash. You can put a small capacitor (say 1 nF) across the NE-2 and have it blink a few times, or flash while testing ionisers. Obviously you don't need the neon bulb, and it cuts off at about 60 volts, so it leaves you slightly charged. You can just use a 1 meg resistor if you want, but I like the flash feedback of successful discharge. You won't feel the residual charge.

description.text: Having tried a couple of spool holder designs I found they didn't seem very strong - they didn't use much material and I could snap them in half with my bare hands. Not liking the idea of it breaking in the middle of the night I set about designing my own. I wanted to see what the Design Spark Mechanical freeware was like so I used that. The 125 Meter cardboard spools from Diamond Age which is about 100mm radius set the spool size to accommodate, but here is room for 125mm. I printed in PLA and could have used less material but I wasn't to bothered about saving a few grams of PLA so left as is. I use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5634 to hold the spool.

I tried Slic3r and Cura to slice.  For Cura I used 1.2mm shells and 0.8mm top and bottom and about 40% infil.  When I tried Slic3r I used the honey comb infill.  This should be a snug fit on to the 8mm Threaded Rod - you may need to warm it up with some hot air to get it to fit, the idea being that I didn't want it to flop around when changing spools.

title: Dual E3D Extruder for RepRapPro Mendel

description.text:
I liked the simple design of the OB1.4 Dual E3D extruder from downeym, so I remixed it to fit on the RepRapPro Mendel carriage.
It replaces the complete front nozzel mount of the carriage, so its easy to swap it with the original.
I placed also two holes in the mounting cap to mount a 50mm fan.

I have updated the design for better airflow through the cold end to the sides and not so much to the hot end.
There is now also a possibility to mount PLA fan ducts on the side.
I added a much simpler version of the carriage. It should work also with the newer E3D-V6 hot-end and its new embedded bowden coupling (not tested, because I haven't one).

Even more simple to print !
