Even more simple than my Simple Filament Spool Stand V2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281848).

No additional parts needed, you just print 2 sides + 1 bar, you clip them and you're done !!
No bearings, No screws, No washers !!
Just print and clip !
This version works with Standard Spools of 1Kg of 1.75mm filament and Printrbot spools.
[update:]The stand is 10 cm tall. So it's very easy to scale up (110% will give you 11cm tall, 120% > 12cm and so on).
[update 04/25/14:] Following people's requests, i added 2 new length bars : 130 mm long an 150 mm long:
  • spool_stand_v3_bar_130mm.stl
  • spool_stand_v3_bar_150mm.stl
    If you have bigger spools: just scale the models !

Just print with 2 perimeters / 30% infill :
  • 2 x spool_stand_v3_side.stl
  • 1 x spool_stand_v3_bar.stl
    Clip them and you're done !
    if you want to make us famous, print one side or even both sides with our name :
    spool_stand_3_side_3DMM.stl
    If your 3D printer is not well calibrated you may need to sandpaper the end tips of the bar, that's all.
    Tip : Place your spool with the filament coming from the bottom, not top, it will be more stable.

description.text:
Very good for optimizing dynamics.
Original DXF File from www.dxf-world.de. Short video at 100mm/sec printing speed. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VL9fR7SdSBw&feature=youtu.be

Mod to decrease temperature on the UP! mini (or Plus) printer. For every increase in number on the wheel I get 5C less on the print head. 0 = no change, 9 = about -45C Needed:
  • printed STL for mod case
  • Cherry PAAA3000 decimal switch (Farnell SKU 1180017)
  • JST BXH-001T-P0.6 crimp terminal, 1 pc. (Farnell SKU 1516301)
  • 1.8ohm resistors (0805 or 0603)
  • some cable

Wire the resistors in series on the push wheel, one wire gets from thermistor to 0 pin and one goes from common to printer.
Depending on the number selected, the common lead picks up on the respective number. Wiring diagram and other details from the forum where I got inspired.
http://www.pp3dp.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=28&t=23922 I took out one terminal from the connector then put in the wire (soldered the end before) and slid over a heat shrink tube. Electrical tape would also work but it can come off due to heat and movement of the head. The JST BXH-001T-P0.6 crimp terminal was used inside the connector crimped to the returning wire from the mod. Remember to test the device with a multimeter before installing. On the side of the casing are two holes (3mm dia, 2mm deep). I used 2 pcs. 3mm dia 2mm height magnets to fix the mod to the outside of the UP! enclosure.

comments.text:
Afinia are still made by pp3dp and rebranded. Same hardware as the UP!.
The trimpots are used to ajust correct temperature reported by the hotend thermistor. I didn't want to touch them.
If the attached mod is set at 0 then everything is back to normal.
It helps for other filaments to lower the extrusion temp, rarerly but is easier for me that way, no need to open the printer and also pretty precise - 5 degrees C per number, giving me a max 45C decrese in temp at number 9.
comments.author: ccc

comments.text:
interesting...
I have the Afinia which I believe is just a newer version of the UP!'s, .. the control board looks basically the same... and use two (tiny) trim-pots to adjust nozzle temperature. One is a 100 ohm and the other is 10 ohm, wired in series. Those two allow adjustment anywhere from room temp to maximum.
I was messing with wax filament and needed a much cooler extruder.
Rough it in with the 100 ohm. The 10 ohm is for fine adjustment. One ohm changes temp by about 3 degrees if memory serves... Super accurate temperature controllers on these machines.. holds it steady within a degree or so.
The software temp readout is way off and some adding or subtracting is needed, but at least it's hackable.

This is a single scale for making scale mail (chainmail with scales).

There's nothing complex about it, just print a few hundred and link them together with jump rings. It is tedious maintaining the correct topology until you get a good plate going, but then it starts going fairly quickly.
Settings: Mosaic printer, PLA, 0.25mm layer height (part is 1mm exactly) 2 solid layers and 2 perimeters so part is completely solid. Infill doesn't matter as there is none.I slice them 5x4 in slic3 to get a plate of 20 per print. I can build the mail about as fast as a plate can print, so it's convenient to just print and build continuously.
The pattern I'm using is simple; each scale is connected by two rings to the two scales diagonally above it. Check the pics for details.
I had ordered a few hundred in stainless from TheRingLord, but while waiting decided to print my own and practice assembling them.
Edit: I enlarged the hole so it would loosen up a bit with the 3/16" rings I'm using. File: scale_bighole.

comments.text: These aren't bad, but you might want to try putting the center bend into them like TheRingLord does. The final maille piece will come out looking very rounded and formed around the wearer rather than a little "bristle-esque" as if the scales were leather. Then again that's a good look as well, so maybe it's worth having both versions.

comments.text: If you have the option use the print preview you can tell if it's the slicer or your printer. There's a good reason why it could be the slicer because those parts are .68mm thick walls which, if you've got a .4mm nozzle means the slicer might see that as being too thin to print (the plastic can't get in and back out) so it just ignores it. Now some slicers like makerware or to a lesser degree Simplify3D doesn't have that problem because they do what's called spurs, in other words they don't need the nozzle to get in and back out because they'll so single walls in some cases.

description.text:
Custom arm so I could use this motor: http://www.headsuphobby.com/Firepower-250-Sport-Outrunner-Brushless-Electric-Motor-E-530.htm
Every other motor seems to be out of stock. down side is the prop saver is part of the motor. I think a file and time could make a prop adapter work with it. Custom bottom deck split into 2 pieces so it would fit on my print bed.
and top deck also split to fit on my print bed.

For the deck and top plate, print 2 of each piece to make the whole part. I used 4-40 machine screws and blind nuts to bolt the 2 halves together. You could add CA glue to the parts before bolting for a more permanent bond.  
Arms print as normal I used my control horn screws to mount the motors. i believe these were 2.5mm self taping screws.

comments.text: Nice work! Printed the bottom plate and it seems real sturdy. One question however; why did you put the top plate on its side? The bottom plate printed just fine with supports. Not complaining, I can rotate it easily enough.. just wondering if you had a specific reason to put it on its side.

title: HBP Thumb wheel  (for hex and square nuts)

description.text:
These thumb wheels are to make HBP adjustments easy when using upgrades such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6558 I found some thumb wheel designs around thingiverse but the reason I decided to make my own was because they were all for hex nuts. When I bought the aluminum HBP kit, it came with square nuts which dont work for these designs.
I made 2 files, one for hex nuts and another for square nuts.

Download the file corresponding to your nut type (square or Hex)
My gcode settings were
30% object infill
.3 layer height
1 shells
35 mm/s feedrate
Refer to pictures for wheel placement.

description.text:
A replacement set of controls if you have sticky buttons or just prefer a more industrial feel to your 3D printer. NOTE: added a shallow body and a mounting blank Using a small micro-switch joystick + 2 momentary push buttons for select and reset with shroud to prevent accidental pressing + a switch for those of you that have fitted LED lighting and a separate "back box" with a 5 degree angle.
The front panel will glue to the surround and the angled face mounts to your printer (choose your angle up or down before glue), all should fit over your existing buttons but you can choose your own fixing method.

I printed in PLA, 100% for the fascia part and 30% for the surround, 0.27mm layers. Part list included as a text file... Control Joystick

A clock with a chain that rotates around the minute shaft. Once every hour a number will be at the top.
It uses a regular quarts motor for wall mounted clocks.
The design is inspired by a clock made by Andreas Dober 1993 for Anthologie Quartett.

Print one sets of numbers, face plate, one drive gear and one ring gear (optional). The chain is made out of 12x12=144 pieces of links so they speak for themselves. I printed these out on a mendel prusa @ 0.2mm thick with ABS plastic. The chain links are designed with supports added for the studs in the .stl file. Simply break away the supports and ream/drill out the holes so that they are nice and round. Then the links should, with a little care, snap together. The c-c distance is 10mm. The clock motor I sourced form my local hardware store and is made for 10 to 12 mm thick face plates.
http://www.clasohlson.com/se/Kvartsverk/Pr341322000
Cut down the hour shaft and fit the drive gear on the minute shaft. I actually managed to fit a 4x8 ball bearing that supports the minute shaft but I think it should work either way. The numbers are glued into the 2x2mm hole in a chain link. Make sure that the chain is free and that the gears are smooth. Enjoy!
